title: The Gendarme in New York
descriptions:
“The Gendarme in New York” (1965) is a French comedy that follows the misadventures of the bumbling yet prideful Saint-Tropez gendarme Ludovic Cruchot and his troop as they travel to New York City for an international police conference. Fresh off their provincial triumphs, the gendarmes are thrilled to represent France, but Cruchot’s excitement is complicated by his teenage daughter, Nicole, who secretly stows away on the transatlantic liner to join him.

Upon arrival, the French unit—decked out in immaculate uniforms and bursting with pomp—collides headlong with the chaos and speed of Manhattan. Cultural misunderstandings and language barriers fuel a cascade of comic set pieces: mistaken addresses, bafflement at American policing methods, and slapstick encounters with New York traffic, modern gadgets, and towering skyscrapers. Cruchot, determined to maintain dignity and order, instead becomes the epicenter of embarrassment as he attempts to impress foreign colleagues with speeches and demonstrations that go spectacularly awry.

Meanwhile, Nicole, hiding her presence to avoid her father’s wrath, slips into a whirlwind tour of New York’s bright lights. She befriends other youths and flirts with the glamour and temptations of the city, prompting Cruchot—once he discovers she’s there—to launch a covert mission to find her without alerting his superiors. His efforts to juggle conference duties with clandestine paternal patrols lead to frantic chases through hotels, museums, and Central Park, as well as comic entanglements with immigration authorities who are none too pleased by a runaway stowaway.

The French gendarmes, trying to adapt to American procedures, end up generating more commotion than control: a demonstration at the conference devolves into physical comedy; an attempt to adopt modern “scientific” policing ends with gadgets malfunctioning; and a goodwill outing gets them lost in the city’s grid. Cruchot’s bluster and unwavering sense of duty clash constantly with New York’s fast-talking locals, culminating in a series of misidentifications that place him at the center of an accidental manhunt.

As Nicole’s escapade grows riskier, Cruchot’s paternal instincts override protocol. His search crescendos aboard the docks and in bustling Midtown, where near-misses and slapstick chaos ensue: elevators jam, revolving doors trap him, and a parade provides unintended cover for his pursuit. Ultimately, father and daughter are reunited after a harum-scarum pursuit resolves in classic farce, with Cruchot forced to swallow his pride and admit his failings while still trying to present an unruffled front to his colleagues.

In the finale, a hastily concocted cover story saves face for the French delegation, who depart New York convinced they have represented their country with honor—despite the trail of comedic confusion left in their wake. Cruchot, relieved that Nicole is safe and forgiven, reassures himself that he has preserved both family and professional dignity, even as fate delivers one last comic twist to puncture his self-importance.

A buoyant entry in the popular Gendarme series, the film blends fish-out-of-water humor with affectionate caricatures of both French provincial pride and American urban hustle. Louis de Funès’s elastic expressions and frantic energy drive the laughs as Cruchot lurches from authority to anarchy and back again, while New York’s iconic settings provide a lively playground for international misunderstandings, father-daughter warmth, and polished slapstick.
